entity1.name: plants
entity1.description: Living organisms that typically produce their food through photosynthesis and form a crucial part of the ecosystem.;;;A living organism that typically produces its own food through photosynthesis.;;;The physical world or universe, especially in its entirety as distinct from human civilization; includes all living organisms and their interactions with the environment.;;;Multicellular eukaryotic organisms that are typically photosynthetic and have cell walls.;;;Molecules used for communication between organisms, often to elicit a response or behavior.;;;Multicellular eukaryotic organisms belonging to the kingdom Plantae, characterized by their ability to perform photosynthesis.;;;A living organism that typically grows in a fixed location and performs photosynthesis.;;;Communities of living organisms in conjunction with the nonliving components of their environment, interacting as a system.;;;Multicellular organisms that produce their own food through photosynthesis and often engage in symbiotic relationships with microbes.;;;Volatile Organic Compounds, chemicals that can easily turn into vapor or gas and are often used in communication between plants.;;;Plants that are located in close proximity to each other and can interact through various means such as chemical signaling.;;;The region of soil in the vicinity of plant roots where there is biological activity due to the presence of root-secreted chemicals and associated microorganisms.;;;Living organisms that are typically characterized by their ability to produce oxygen and organic compounds through photosynthesis.;;;Multicellular organisms that are capable of photosynthesis and form the basis of most terrestrial ecosystems.;;;The scientific study of plants, including their structure, growth, reproduction, physiology, and ecology.;;;A symbiotic association between fungi and the roots of vascular plants, facilitating nutrient exchange.;;;Fungi that form symbiotic associations with plant roots, aiding in the absorption of nutrients and water from the soil.;;;Microscopic organisms, which can be single-celled or multicellular, including bacteria, fungi, archaea, and protists.;;;A community of living organisms (plants, animals, and microbes) in conjunction with the nonliving components of their environment (air, water, and mineral soil), interacting as a system.;;;A method of communication in which plants release chemical substances to convey information or signals to other organisms.;;;Multicellular eukaryotic organisms that are capable of photosynthesis, typically having roots, stems, and leaves.;;;A symbiotic association between fungi and the roots of plants, forming a network that facilitates nutrient exchange and communication among plants.;;;Invertebrate animals of the class Insecta, characterized by a chitinous exoskeleton, a three-part body (head, thorax, and abdomen), and six jointed legs.;;;Living organisms that are typically sessile and capable of photosynthesis.;;;Living organisms that can sense environmental changes and adjust their growth patterns.;;;Living organisms that are typically rooted in the ground and have a photosynthetic mode of nutrition.;;;Animals that transfer pollen from one flower to another, aiding in plant reproduction.;;;The observable actions or reactions of plants in response to environmental stimuli.;;;The interaction between plant roots and soil microorganisms that occurs in the region of soil surrounding the roots.;;;Living things in the vicinity that can cause vibrations sensed by plants.;;;A group of carbon-based chemicals that easily evaporate at room temperature.;;;A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.;;;Microorganisms that have a positive impact on plant growth and health, often by enhancing nutrient uptake or protecting against pathogens.;;;Signals used in communication between cells or organisms, often involving the release of molecules that can be detected by other cells or organisms.;;;Substances produced by plants to protect themselves against herbivores or pathogens, often having toxic or deterrent properties.;;;A broad term encompassing all forms of life, including plants, animals, fungi, and microorganisms.;;;Signals produced by microorganisms that can affect plant growth and development through interactions with the plant's roots or leaves.;;;Multicellular organisms that are capable of photosynthesis and play a crucial role in the ecosystem.;;;A diverse group of carbon-based chemicals that easily evaporate at room temperature and are often used by plants for communication and defense.;;;Substances that are formed by the chemical union of two or more elements in definite proportions.;;;Bacteria capable of converting atmospheric nitrogen into a form usable by plants, thus enhancing soil fertility.;;;Multicellular organisms that are capable of photosynthesis and typically have roots, stems, and leaves.;;;Multicellular organisms that are typically characterized by their ability to produce oxygen and organic compounds through photosynthesis.;;;The study of how plants interact and exchange information with each other.;;;A form of communication among plants that helps them defend against threats and coordinate responses to environmental changes.;;;The process by which plants exchange information with each other, often through chemical signals or physical connections such as mycorrhizal networks.;;;Animals or insects that transfer pollen from one flower to another, aiding in plant reproduction.;;;Plants located in close proximity to each other, capable of interacting through various means including chemical signaling.;;;Underground networks formed by the hyphae of fungi, which connect individual plants and facilitate nutrient exchange.;;;Multicellular organisms that are typically photosynthetic and have cell walls.;;;Microscopic living organisms, including bacteria, fungi, archaea, and protists.;;;Microscopic organisms that can form symbiotic relationships with plants.;;;Molecules or compounds used by organisms to communicate with each other, often influencing behavior or physiological processes.;;;The region of soil in the vicinity of plant roots where there is biological activity due to root exudates and associated microorganisms.;;;Animals that assist in the pollination process by transferring pollen between plants.;;;A system of interconnected organisms or structures that facilitate the exchange of resources and information.

entity8.name: air
entity8.description: The mixture of gases that surrounds the Earth and is essential for the survival of most terrestrial life forms.

entity11.name: herbivores
entity11.description: Animals that feed on plant material as their primary food source.;;;Animals that feed on plants as their primary diet.;;;An animal that feeds on plants or plant material as the main component of its diet.
entity11.chunkid: How Plants Communicate6;;;How Plants Communicate23;;;How Plants Communicate7

entity17.name: roots
entity17.description: The underground part of a plant that typically functions to anchor the plant and absorb water and nutrients from the soil.

entity21.name: nutrients
entity21.description: Essential substances required for the growth and survival of living organisms.

entity22.name: water
entity22.description: A chemical substance that is composed of hydrogen and oxygen atoms, essential for the survival of most known forms of life.

entity33.name: nectar
entity33.description: A sweet liquid produced by plants to attract pollinators and provide a food source for them.

entity34.name: pollen
entity34.description: Fine powder produced by the male parts of flowers, which is essential for plant reproduction and serves as a food source for some pollinators.

entity39.name: Soil
entity39.description: The upper layer of earth in which plants grow, consisting of rock and mineral particles mixed with organic matter.

entity42.name: root exudates
entity42.description: Substances released by plant roots into the soil, which can include sugars, organic acids, and other compounds that influence microbial activity.

entity53.name: physical cues
entity53.description: External stimuli that can influence the behavior or responses of an organism, such as touch and vibrations in plants.

entity58.name: wind
entity58.description: A natural movement of air, often causing vibrations in plants.

entity64.name: physical signals
entity64.description: Stimuli from the physical environment that can influence biological processes, such as light, temperature, and mechanical forces.

entity66.name: environment
entity66.description: The surroundings or conditions in which an organism lives, including both biotic (living) and abiotic (non-living) factors.
